title: <italic>Usf1</italic>, a suppressor of the circadian <italic>Clock</italic> mutant, reveals the nature of the DNA-binding of the CLOCK:BMAL1 complex in mice
abstract: Genetic and molecular approaches have been critical for elucidating the mechanism of the mammalian circadian clock. Here, we demonstrate that the <italic>ClockΔ19</italic> mutant behavioral phenotype is significantly modified by mouse strain genetic background. We map a suppressor of the <italic>ClockΔ19</italic> mutation to a ∼900 kb interval on mouse chromosome 1 and identify the transcription factor, <italic>Usf1</italic>, as the responsible gene. A SNP in the promoter of <italic>Usf1</italic> causes elevation of its transcript and protein in strains that suppress the <italic>Clock</italic> mutant phenotype. USF1 competes with the CLOCK:BMAL1 complex for binding to E-box sites in target genes. Saturation binding experiments demonstrate reduced affinity of the CLOCKΔ19:BMAL1 complex for E-box sites, thereby permitting increased USF1 occupancy on a genome-wide basis. We propose that USF1 is an important modulator of molecular and behavioral circadian rhythms in mammals.
